text: Mask/Anti-mask...false argument. Masks were never designed or promoted as a means to reduce/prevent the transmission of viral agents. Masks were designed to prevent droplets and therefore the bacteria in those droplets from entering the body via incisions during surgery (pre-covid, hospital staff, exposed to all manner of ailments from the general public, did not run around in masks all day and somehow they all didn't get sick or die). 30,000-60,000 in the US die from influenza every year; 3000 people per day die from tuberculosis -- if effective, why were masks never mandated? Were these deaths acceptable? One study pointed out that, not only are masks not effective in preventing the spread of viruses, but there was no understanding of whether longterm use would be detrimental and that more research is needed. My position has been: If research eventually shows longterm use to be detrimental, who would be held accountable for having mandated them? The answer is that no one will be held personally liable. Ultimately, any settlements that would be paid would come from taxpayers. Government has no business telling free people what to wear. If the color blue was shown to calm schizophrenics, would we all be forced to wear blue for the public good? If I don't want to wear blue 24-7-365, does it mean I don't care about schizophrenics? It's all nonsense as well as unconstitutional. From a commonsensical perspective, if these measures were effective, why haven't cases declined precipitously? There empirical evidence is in: there is no statistically significant difference in excess death or the number of cases in states that locked down and those that didn't.

text:
You and Barnes make the same mistake with your mics. LISTEN UP: It does not need to be so close to your mouth or even pointing at your face. It's "condenser mic" that emits a "cardioid" shaped field out in front of the mic to pick up your voice. Depending on the power setting (gain control) I could have the mic 3 ft from my face and it will pick up all the audio just fine. You do not need so much of the mic or stand in the frame. It's also much more likely that you will bump it etc with your setup. Just put your headphones on and listen to the sound at various distances and gain settings. You'll be surprised how far away you can put it. 

The reason amateurs get confused is cuz that they see performers use live "dynamic" mics that the singer holds close to their mouth to control the power essentially. You are not doing this - you are not using a dynamic mic. 

Barnes utterly ignored my input, my guess is you will too....

text:
I find it interesting that the scientific research into the efficacy of masks basically matches the pre-covid research, but those with a political agenda cherry-pick just what they want to hear. That's not how science works, you don't get to disregard all of the information that disagrees with you and point at just the bits that confirm your claim. If you're allowed to do that, climate change deniers can prove that all the science confirms their opinions, for example. The science becomes meaningless. I said it in February of last year: don't require people to wear masks until you have a mask medically proven to be safe and effective for this use case, provided them to everyone, and with significant information about how to properly wear and handle them. Unless you follow that approach, you just end up with a mess and they won't work. That's because I read the studies. I can understand feeling like it's an emergency so we need to quickly get a solution, but that sense of urgency doesn't mean they're going to suddenly do what the science says they won't.

The reason nobody had anything like this ready is the same reason no country was ready for a pandemic. We just don't have the means to deal with a pandemic. In the future, with RNA vaccine technology, we'll be able to get massive numbers of vaccines out in a hurry, and that can be a valid response coupled with true lockdowns, but not if it takes months. We don't have masks available even today that are medically proven effective against two-way aerosol transmission, and contact tracing is largely infeasible. We just don't have an answer, so let's do the most reasonable thing: make sure mRNA vaccines are safe and be able to pump them out and get ahead of things like this, instead of futilely flailing in the wind hoping to stop a hurricane.

text:
Yo dude you‚Äôre getting way too invested in Twitter. Watched you since before the first impeachment, probably under 10k subs. So when I say this, it‚Äôs based on my experience watching you for the past few years. 

Over the past 6 months or so you‚Äôve been slowly becoming more and more irritable, and it‚Äôs always from reading news, and from your own admission, using twitter to vent. And while the news is enraging for everyone, it‚Äôs exponentially increased by Twitter. In my opinion, it‚Äôs a combination of putting everyone with a low social credit score under ‚Äúmore replies‚Äù, and limiting the number of characters you can tweet. What that effectively does is erase the nuances of very complex discussion and instead opts to make opinions as dumbed down, generic, and digestible as possible. TLDR: it‚Äôs for stupid people. 

Most of us ‚Äúconservatives‚Äù took the step, whether voluntarily or not, to leave the platform. I can say it‚Äôs drastically improved my mental well-being. I worry that you‚Äôre undergoing the same process that I, and many others experienced; and that can cause real world impact with your family and friends. Don‚Äôt let it. 

Get your news from other sources, other platforms will just screencap tweets and have their own discussion instead of driving traffic and having to engage. Patriots.win, gab, (NOT Parler), plus Mike Lindell‚Äôs new platform is launching this week, Trump‚Äôs in May. But funnily enough, probably the best place for news discussion on the internet is 4chan‚Äôs /pol/ board. It‚Äôs basically the complete opposite of Twitter, but the discussion and news of the day cycles through without the absence of meaningful discussion.

/pol/ takes some getting used to but here‚Äôs some quick tips: First, antisemitism is rampant on /pol/, because it‚Äôs one big role playing session. It‚Äôs regularly promoted by Israelis funnily enough. We know this because your country flag will show, vpns and proxies are banned, so it‚Äôs all in good fun. Your first reaction will be to say antisemitism is bad. But you actually want to do the opposite. This is because by default, you must assume everyone on 4chan is either a cop, or a troll and is baiting you, because they are. It‚Äôs one big psychological operation, except you‚Äôre on your guard by default. That skepticism helps in the interpretation of current events. The world is still burning around you, but you just learn to better deal with it. Don‚Äôt ask me why, but /pol/ is ironically one of the best forums of discussion, you just have to filter the trolling, and you learn quickly, almost like a survival instinct. I think taking a break from Twitter would be good for you either way, and there‚Äôs healthier options.

Things to look forward to using /pol/ if you do check it out:
-You will become an expert on World War 2 history, global politics in places today like the UK, Australia, Taiwan, Russia, Ukraine, Poland, etc. This is because you can tell where people are from immediately in most cases, and their opinion holds weight when you can see whose who, as opposed to the fallacy of twitter, where not immediately knowing leads you to automatically assume you‚Äôre speaking to someone in the US or Canada, thus giving their opinion more weight. For some reason it‚Äôs exactly the opposite on /pol/, you know they‚Äôre not your countrymen, but their opinion does provide better perspective.

-How to better handle people and drive the conversation, anywhere on the internet. Often this is done through empirical sources, and memes.

-You will be able to meme. For real now.

-You will be able to better control what deserves your attention, what is a distraction, and what you should be discussing on other platforms that is often entirely overlooked or suppressed.

-You will be able to better identify fake news, and often won‚Äôt even have to look at why something is or isn‚Äôt true, because it will be immediately provided to you, either in the thread itself as a reply, or ahead of the fake news story itself.

-You will be kept better informed on current events than on Twitter, unless it‚Äôs on a local level.

4chan is filled with some of the most highly educated and intellectual people you will ever meet, although it may not seem that way on the surface. Just remember what I said above, and you‚Äôll do fine.

text:
On the topic of masks at 4:00, because the face masks being sold to the public, in most jurisdictions, are not being sold as medical PPE they only have to meet lower "generally safe" standards for toxic materials.  

One report I saw out of the UK found samples of face masks containing PFC based compounds to make the exterior blue side of the mask water repellant.  Such PFC chemicals wouldn't be uncommon on a backpack or a rain jacket, and they normally wouldn't be near your mouth or nose where you might inhale them as they rub off the fibers, so the generally safe standard is perfectly fine in the context of a backpack or jacket.  It's probably not acceptable for a face mask, and while I don't know for sure it probably wouldn't meet the standard for medical grade face masks.

text:
"I'm not religious" Real quick - this is a common misconception.  The short version, a religious belief is a structure of philosophy which informs your moral frame work. All philosophical and moral frame works are, in the end, accepted on principles of faith and belief. Those frames can be well reasoned, accepted from authority, or derived from impulse and instinct. But the base level axioms, the core truths that you might hold self evident, are matters of faith.

Such as, human rights exist.

The egregious and overbearing point of contention with much of the current woke cult, and the left in general, is that they have discarded the separation of their Church and the State on the grounds that they themselves are not religious and, therefore, do not have the faults of a religious person or a religious doctrine. They remain blind to the fact that the faults they saw in "religion" were in fact faults found in man. And if you believe yourself above making a mistake, you will inevitably commit it.

text:
Xechran, precisely! If one believes in inherent human rights, the rights of man, inalienable rights, or the concept of a social contract; then one is operating on a theological basis, whether one is cognizant of that bedrock or not. It is a categorical error to conflate being possessed of a system of belief with active participation in some formal religious institution.

If you dig below the surface, you will find that nearly all agnostics and atheists are adherents to a system of belief. They simply take issue with the imperfect and frequently corrupt laws and institutions of man. It is a critical error to reject all law and all institutions. The cruelty, suffering, and injustice that result from chaos are without limit, and for most of us beyond out imagination.

The laws of god are unerring and perfect. The laws of man are predictably imperfect. Just as god is perfect, and man, made in his image, is born imperfect.

So, the host of this video is religious, although not fully conscious of this fact. He is not devout.

¬†@Matt M¬† the circle experiment is set up so the group, believed to be random folks, will never agree or change their mind cause the setup is they are stooges, part of the experiment.  They are out there under disguise to purposefully make it feel like they aren‚Äôt involved.  The whole purpose of them is to force the issue, to give bad answers, to see what the only person for whom is actually being monitored will do.  Will that individual go along with the group think even though it is obvious their wrong or will they speak up, effectively going against the grain.  Conclusion, a large majority goes along to get along.  So it is the exact opposite of what you‚Äôd like to happen.
As stated, most think there would be now way as a regular citizen who found themselves in the past that they‚Äôd ever go along to get along with the status quo.  The evidence doesn‚Äôt bare this out.
The folks that drove and managed the trains to extermination camps could not have all been utterly disdainful people.  Years earlier these were everyday people, just trying live a life and do their job.  So what transpired that allowed them to participate in such acts of human atrocity?  And why do most think they‚Äôd be the odd man out who risks it all to speak up and say this is horrible and I‚Äôm not gonna do it?
The status quo is powerful and most reason away their actions in relation to their deeds.
The health authority folks that went to that restaurant easily reason away their tyranny enforcement actions.  Failing to recognize that these folks have a vested interest in reasoning their acts away or outright denying they have any free will in the matter or that they aren‚Äôt doing anything immoral and placing your trust to hope is only seceding the battle.  
By far the vast majority will be the status quo.  I accept that.  I have not lost hope myself that simply because the status quo is unlikely to budge that the battle is lost.  It is not.
I don‚Äôt need to convince everyone in the status quo that making pot illegal is wrong on so many levels.  The seeds of its own destruction are down into the action itself.  It‚Äôs a failure and won‚Äôt last.  Today, now that pot is legal many of those that were the status quo would readily tell you they think it‚Äôs fine.  Worse, they forget they believed otherwise earlier, that they were the resistance.  I don‚Äôt need to get everyone to agree on all points in order to drag them along kicking and screaming.  I am an optimist, cause the absurdity of their actions will ultimately fail on its own.  I just don‚Äôt care to wait for the edifice to come crashing down but instead desire to tear it down, on their heads of need be.  Equally I am a realist.  Meaning, I don‚Äôt give into to rosy, make me feel better platitudes about hope and one day the rest will see the light.  Perhaps some, but history and evidence suggests most won‚Äôt.  Though some will after the fact and claim they were always in agreement m.

author: Matt M

text:
¬†@Matt M¬† I am not saying a select few are speaking up as was the case in the Vancouver restaurant.  I am saying to believe that the overwhelming number of NPC‚Äôs are unlikely to ever come about unless they are forced to or are dragged kicking and screaming.
The cultist‚Äôs, the emotional reasoners, are not the type that change their tune so readily.  
Everyone thinks if they were transported back in time, say to Germany, there is no way they‚Äôd given into the group think and status quo of the time, fascism.  Most of these people are naive.  
The status quo provides so much and that is why it is a limited small fraction of people who actually speak out.  You highlighting this small group does not an argument make that others will follow in large numbers.
Those that speak up are labelled as fringe, COVID idiots, conspiracists, selfish, etc.
Look it there are ample psychological experiments which bare this out.  A classic is the one that examines an individual amongst a crowd and whether or not that individual will speak what they know is truth but which simultaneously goes against the group.  Here‚Äôs three circles, which one is larger .... clearly the answer is A, but the group all says B.  Everyone likes to think they‚Äôd hold fast to their principles and risk standing out against the crowd.  In reality, it‚Äôs a unique individual that actually does so.
Long story short ... most folks do a cost benefit analysis and conclude, the risk is not worth the gain.  Perhaps when the risk of not speaking up becomes so grave these same people may be willing to take the risk.  Very often the ship has sailed at that point.  Meaning, the effective and appropriate time to have spoken up is past.  
Take cancel culture.  Many are silent even many may feel something about it doesn‚Äôt sit well.  Yet the time to speak up is present.  However, the day the cancel culture hits home, say a daughter loses her job for dubious reasons, is when they finally have the risk / reward equation in their favour but by now it‚Äôs too late.  The damage is done.
Having said all that, I do acknowledge and agree with your original post.  Thank goodness there are those brave enough and principled enough that do speak truth to power and there are many that are in agreement with them even though they may not be in a reasonable position to speak up themselves.  But I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs useful nor realistic to hold the view that so long as enough time is given, don‚Äôt worry, the rest will eventually see the light.  
Whether or not these folks ever see the light the idea should be the rest of us are not waiting, hoping, the fight to speak truth to power will forage ahead with or without those others.  Whether they like it or not, agree or not, it‚Äôs irrelevant to the fact folks like those in the restaurant will not play nice.

text: ¬†@bcshu2¬† yes but a variant of this experiment is: a person walks into a waiting room. One other person is already there. A bell goes off and the person already in the room stands. The bell goes off and they sit. The person stands or sits every time the bell goes off. The new person will begin to do the same. More people come in one at a time and everyone ends up following the pattern. But interestingly if ONE person speaks up and questions what's going on, the whole thing falls apart. So it shows that vocal minorities can influence the behaviour of the entire group  The leftists are a small group who have influenced all our behaviour. It was possible for them to disrupt the main group. It's possible for us to do it too! It's not hopeless

text:
They are, 23 thousands deaths total in the last year or 2 of this pandemic, I think

And according to this source (https://www.statista.com/statistics/443061/number-of-deaths-in-canada/) , there have been 300k reported deaths between June 2019 & 2020, so anyways that‚Äôs about ~7.7 % if you make a conservative comparison, so Idk what to you‚Äôre talking about. Why do you think that ‚Äúpandemic‚Äù should be anonymous to a matter of actual Martial Law & a sign of the end times ? That‚Äôs just not how mature scientists defined the term, and that‚Äôs how it‚Äôs always been... 

To compare, according to this April 2009 article (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4634693/) , which focused on only 14 European countries, or 75% of its population, the worst example of a ‚Äúpandemic‚Äù (for which we‚Äôve define the term as such, btw) that hit the Contemporary Era and gave us reliable enough stats, the Spanish Flu, has had an ESTIMATED 2.64 million ‚Äúexcess‚Äù deaths in Europe alone for the whole pandemic. 

‚ÄùExcess deaths are typically defined as the difference between the observed [and the expected] numbers of deaths in specific time periods‚Äù (https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nvss/vsrr/covid19/excess_deaths.htm)

So already, we can tell that the COVID-19 is already in the same league and ballpark as the Spanish Flu it-fucking-self in terms of danger (It has a current REPORTED death toll of 2.85M worldwide, and the stats are still growing, though I‚Äôm trying not to sound like a fear-monger or anything) 

Another study (https://www.biospace.com/article/compare-1918-spanish-influenza-pandemic-versus-covid-19/) estimates that the total death toll of the Spanish Flu was in the low dozens of millions, like between 10M or 20M; okay ? 

And, btw, the fact that Earth is now ~5x as more populous then in 1900 (https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Estimates_of_historical_world_population) , & with Europe ~3x bigger than during that time (Oh, and, btw, the death toll of Europe was estimated to be about ~1.1% in that study from before about the estimated death toll of Europe ! ; p) (https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19453486/) then this most probably means (in and of itself, for some reason or another that I won‚Äôt speculate on, as that‚Äôs besides the point), that we‚Äôve done a damn better job this time around & on average at controlling this virus so far. 

And all of this about the Spanish Flu is the absolute worst, and the benchmark for all other pandemics, like this yet incomplete & evolving (in more ways than one) virus

So if we can do smth about the virus, I say we fucking do !!!
